Read more about Laura and her sistersâ€™ journey, about how @BasserBRCA is opening up new horizons for cancer prevention and treatmentâ€”for BRCA and beyond:  http://PennMedicine.org/magazine/basserÂ  pic.twitter.com/dN4RTtPZvO

Yet thatâ€™s just one part of Domchekâ€™s typical day, which veers from the clinic where she sees patients to overseeing @BasserBRCAâ€™s broad mission and slate of activities, from the lab bench to the clinic to educational outreach in at-risk communities.

â€œSisters come to clinic together, or a mom and a daughter,â€ Domchek says. â€œWeâ€™re in it for the long term with families. Weâ€™re with these women through dating, marriage, and children. Itâ€™s a true privilege that happens so rarely in medicine.â€ pic.twitter.com/MssoomRvfs

For Domchek, treating patient-families like theirs is part of a unique style of care at the Basser Center. It feels, she says, as if her practice hearkens back to old-style family physicians who saw multiple generations of patients.

The three sisters all feel a connection with Domchek, who takes time to answer every question they have about their follow-up care and about ongoing research on BRCA that could benefit their children.

Now seven-year survivors of their breast cancer treatments, Temple and Schmidt share the experience of seeing Dr. Susan Domchek at @BasserBRCA for their follow-up care. So does another sister who was treated at @PennMedicine for BRCA-related breast cancer last year.

A ripple effect was seeing her youngest sister, Jen Schmidt, begin breast cancer treatment while she was still undergoing her own. As time went on, the shared BRCA experience also brought the sisters together.

For Laura Temple, the discovery of her BRCA mutation during cancer treatment meant, first, pursuing a more aggressive course to prevent future cancersâ€”a double mastectomy, when initially sheâ€™d hoped for a â€œband-aidâ€ lumpectomy.

The discovery of a BRCA mutation has rippling effects through families, as multiple family in turn may begin their own journeys through the choices of testing, screening, and, in some cases, cancer treatment or preventive surgical procedures. pic.twitter.com/srrwAE4ePC

What we know about the BRCA gene mutations began with familial studies of breast and ovarian cancer and a flurry of competitive research to identify the underlying genes in the early 1990s. @PennMedicine has been at the forefront of such research since the beginning. pic.twitter.com/c4yYjgGMl1
Women with a BRCA2 mutation like Laura and Jen have a 50 to 70 percent lifetime risk of breast cancer and a 10 to 20 percent lifetime risk of ovarian cancer.

Laura discovered that a mutation in the BRCA2 gene ran in her family when she was undergoing treatment for #breastcancer. She had lost her mom to ovarian cancer not long before that. Soon, her youngest sister, Jen, learned she also inherited the gene and had breast cancer, too. pic.twitter.com/dHmAVgI4z2
â€œItâ€™s harder to find out your sister has cancer and a BRCA mutation than to find out for yourself,â€ says Laura Temple, a @BasserBRCA patient. pic.twitter.com/jKP4Rg4ME7

This guy wrote one of the more descriptive medical histories of the 1918 flu. He included the fact that whiskey was one of the only treatments -- and it had to be obtained at a pharmacy. The city closed all bars due to illness. https://twitter.com/PennMedMag/status/967060328583442433Â â€¦

See the rest of the 1918 #influenza story at @PennMedicineâ€”and more on the outlook for future pandemicsâ€”in our @PennMedMag feature by @kategammon:  http://PennMedicine.org/magazine/1918Â And read even more in the @Penn spotlight story here:  https://www.upenn.edu/spotlights/plagued-flu-managing-influenza-1918-and-todayÂ â€¦ pic.twitter.com/1KkKwnzApW
We also know that the question is not â€œifâ€ there will be another outbreak, but only â€œwhenâ€â€”and how much better prepared we will be to handle it when it strikes.
A century later, we know much more about the 1918 outbreak, about preventing influenza, and about surveillance that can identify the next pandemic before it takes hold. pic.twitter.com/64RpJCBTc8

Before the flu epidemic ended, the illness swept the globe. An estimated 50 to 100 million people died worldwideâ€”and one-third of the total human population was sickened. Philadelphia, the hardest-hit American city, got the brunt of the illness.

â€œAfter gasping for several hours they became delirious and incontinent, and many died struggling to clear their airways of a blood-tinged froth that sometimes gushed from their nose and mouth,â€ Starr wrote. â€œIt was a dreadful business.â€

Soon the patients poured in. At first, nobody on Starrâ€™s floor was very illâ€”the patients had fever but little else wrong with them. But over a few days, their illness changed for the worse. The patientsâ€™ lungs filled with sticky phlegm, and they became short of breath.

The shuttered hospital converted to an emergency influenza clinic in the fall of 1918 was the Medico-Chirurgical Hospital of Philadelphia (Image:  http://hdl.library.upenn.edu/1017/d/archives/20030322008Â â€¦) pic.twitter.com/fFBbjqZ9jO

Medical students and city workers constructed a temporary hospital with wooden partitions, based on the skeleton of a hospital recently shuttered at 18th and Cherry Streets to make way for construction of the Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

With so many medical practitioners away in the armed forces, medical studentsâ€™ services were needed in caring for the sick. School was closed for third- and fourth-year students, among them a young man named Isaac Starr. pic.twitter.com/p6thCunSAC
Our story begins a few days after classes began in the fall of 1918. Penn medical students received grave news: An influenza epidemic was judged to be developing in Philadelphia.

In a #flu season as bad as this one, we remember how dangerous this disease can be. Another sobering reminder: The worst known global pandemic happened exactly 100 years ago.In @PennMedMag, we look back and forward at our preparedness for the next outbreak. pic.twitter.com/Uwq3NZB1gL

The rest is historyâ€”and that history is still in the making. You can read about how @PennMedicine achieved the first FDA-approved CAR T cell therapy and where weâ€™re going next in our feature package:  http://PennMedicine.org/magazine/cellebrationÂ â€¦ pic.twitter.com/NItkvukU4A
The results, as described in press reports after they were published in 2011, were â€œspectacular.â€ pic.twitter.com/4b2cl7hTNQ

A billion or so of their T cells were removed, reprogrammed with a modified, harmless HIV virus and taught to seek out that CD19 protein on cancer cells, and then infused back into their bodies to multiply and attack leukemia.

By 2009, the team was ready for human testing. The NIH had declined to fund the work several times over the years. Help from private funders allowed the researchers to now conduct a small trialâ€”just three patients.
He continued: â€œHappy to prove them wrong!â€

Blood cancers would be next. Michael Milone, who came to work on them as a postdoc, said, â€œPeople advised me to think carefully about working with Carl because they said the work he was doing was high-risk and unlikely to be successful.â€

By the time June and @BLLPHD landed at @Penn in 1999, they had cracked the code on how to get T cells to grow outside the body, and safely infused a small group of HIV patients with first-generation chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells that enhanced their immune function.
None of this seemed to discourage Carl June, MD, an immunologist who had been working with modified T cells to develop experimental HIV therapies since the mid-1980s.
Pharmaceutical companies had little interest. Funding was scarce. And people from other biomedical fields largely viewed immunotherapy as a low priority.
The immunotherapy field was still relatively small, with few research groups around the world investigating ways to manipulate the immune systemâ€™s T cells to fight disease.

Itâ€™s 2018. Young leukemia patients now can have their immune cells removed and bioengineered to fight cancerâ€”itâ€™s been an FDA-approved reality for half a year. But 10 years ago, this would have been a pipe dream.

See the rest of the story of Bennett, Maguire, their partnership, their dogs, and the achievement of their gene-therapy vision in the new issue of @PennMedMag, written by @sirosenbaum, here:  http://PennMedicine.org/magazine/visionrealizedÂ â€¦ pic.twitter.com/4rGi0xpA5O
â€œBy putting our two experiences together and our perspectives on things,â€ Bennett says, â€œit really propelled us much further than either one of us could go alone.â€

In December, they hit a milestone unique to them: The FDA approved their treatment for a form of inherited blindness, the first such treatment for a genetic condition ever approved in the U.S.  https://www.pennmedicine.org/news/news-releases/2017/december/fda-approves-gene-therapy-for-inherited-blindness-developed-by-university-of-pennsylvania-and-chopÂ â€¦
Working in tandem for decades at @PennMedicine, Bennett and Maguire became pioneers in the field of gene therapyâ€”a discipline that was science fiction when they met.

But theyâ€™ve also collaborated in ways few married couples have. The dogs were originally laboratory subjects, and the children grew up listening to their parents talk over experimental medical procedures at the dinner table.
After more than 30 years of an extraordinary partnership, Bennett and Maguire have hit a lot of traditional milestones: They have the house, three kids and two dogs. pic.twitter.com/JzVjgGslsO
They tell this story, their meet-cute, with relishâ€”swapping punchlines like the long-married couple they are today.
â€œAs you can tell,â€ she says, â€œI fell for Alâ€™s sense of humor.â€â€œI was especially happy to find out someone else hadnâ€™t used that pickup line on her before,â€ he says.
Instead of recoiling, she wiggled the finger in his grasp. She looked at him. â€œItâ€™s my *second* favorite organ,â€ she replied.And that was that. pic.twitter.com/5ehglbw2zI
He took her gloved hand and gently poked her finger right into the bundle of nerves at the rubbery center of the hypothalamusâ€”the pleasure center. â€œThatâ€™s my favorite organ,â€ he murmured.
Jean Bennett and Albert Maguire were both first-year medical students at Harvard, but Bennett already had a doctorate in zoology. Maguire felt he had to make a grand gesture to catch her eye.
To begin with, they shared a brain.It sat between them on in a tray, smelling of fixative agents. Theyâ€™d already begun cutting into it, and it had flopped open, exposing the hypothalamus.
